revision.text:
{{Infobox film | name = Election | image = Election (1999 film).png | caption = Theatrical release poster | border = no | director = [[Alexander Payne]] | producer = [[Albert Berger (producer)|Albert Berger]]
[[Ron Yerxa]]
David Gale
[[Keith Samples]] | screenplay = Alexander Payne
[[Jim Taylor (writer)|Jim Taylor]] | based on = {{Based on|''[[Election (1998 novel)|Election]]''|[[Tom Perrotta]]}} | starring = {{Plainlist| * [[Matthew Broderick]] * [[Reese Witherspoon]]}} | music = [[Rolfe Kent]] | cinematography = [[James Glennon]] | editing = [[Kevin Tent]] | studio = [[MTV Films|MTV Productions]]
Bona Fide Productions | distributor = [[Paramount Pictures]] | released = {{Film date|1999|5|7}} | runtime = 103 minutes | country = United States | language = English | budget = $25 million | gross = $14.9 million }} '''''Election''''' is a 1999 American [[Black comedy|black]] [[Comedy-drama|comedy-drama film]] directed and written by [[Alexander Payne]] and adapted by him and [[Jim Taylor (writer)|Jim Taylor]] from [[Tom Perrotta]]'s 1998 [[Election (1998 novel)|novel of the same title]]. The plot revolves around a high school election and satirizes both suburban high school life and politics. The film stars [[Matthew Broderick]] as Jim McAllister, a popular high school social studies teacher in suburban [[Omaha, Nebraska]], and [[Reese Witherspoon]] as [[Tracy Flick]], around the time of the school's [[Student governments in the United States|student body]] election. When Tracy qualifies to run for class president, McAllister believes she does not deserve the title and tries to stop her from winning. Although a [[box office bomb]], ''Election'' received critical acclaim. The film received an [[Academy Award]] nomination for [[Academy Award for Best Writing (Adapted Screenplay)|Best Adapted Screenplay]], a [[Golden Globe Award|Golden Globe]] nomination for Witherspoon in the [[Golden Globe Award for Best Actress – Motion Picture Musical or Comedy|Best Actress]] category, and the [[Independent Spirit Award for Best Film]] in 1999. ==Plot== Jim McAllister is a beloved high school teacher living in Omaha, Nebraska, whose enthusiastic involvement in school activities masks his frustration with other aspects of his life. Tracy Flick is an overachieving senior whom Jim sees as having a secret vindictive and sexual side. Earlier in the year, Tracy had an [[Extramarital affair|affair]] with another teacher, Jim's best friend Dave Novotny. When the affair was discovered, Dave was fired and divorced by his wife Linda; Tracy walked away with her reputation unscathed. Tracy announces to Jim, who is in charge of organizing the school's student government, that she is running for [[Student Government President|student body president]], telling him they "will be spending a lot of time together." Jim sees this as unbridled ambition and sexual manipulation, and finds it repugnant. With Tracy appearing to have no opposition, Jim decides to teach Tracy a lesson in humility by encouraging Paul Metzler, to enter the race. Paul is a polite and popular football player, sidelined due to a broken leg, leaving him depressed. Jim convinces Paul to declare his candidacy, giving him new purpose. This serves to bring out Tracy's vindictiveness, as she resents Paul's effortless popularity. Paul's younger sister Tammy is dumped by her lover, Lisa, who says that she is straight and was just "experimenting". Lisa becomes Paul's girlfriend and [[campaign manager]]. In retaliation, Tammy decides to run for president as well, with a nihilistic platform that student government is a sham. During a school assembly to hear the candidates' final campaign speeches, Tracy draws polite applause while Paul initially receives a warm reception despite giving a lackluster and halting speech, while Tammy delivers a defiant address in which she denounces the election and expresses her intention to dissolve the student government if elected. This rallies the student body to a [[standing ovation]]. As a result of her subversive speech, Tammy is suspended. While working on a yearbook project, Tracy notices that one of her posters has come untaped from the wall. Attempting to fix it, she accidentally rips the poster apart. In a fit of frustrated rage, she destroys Paul's [[Campaign advertising|campaign posters]]. The following day when Jim confronts Tracy with his suspicion that she was responsible, Tracy claims innocence and threatens [[legal action]] against the school. Tammy falsely confesses to Tracy's crime even though she witnessed Tracy disposing of the posters. Tammy's name is removed from the ballot, she is expelled and her parents enroll her in a private [[parochial school]] for girls, much to her delight. The day before the election, Jim visits Linda's house to help her with a home repair project, whereupon she initiates a physical relationship by kissing him. Linda asks Jim to rent a motel room for an after-school rendezvous, but never shows up at the motel. When Jim drives over to Linda's house to see what happened, he is stung by a bee on his right eyelid, causing a severe allergic reaction. He returns home to find Linda and his wife talking together. Knowing he has been caught, he spends the night in his car. The next morning — Election Day — Jim's eyelid is disfigured from the bee sting, but he must oversee the counting of the election [[ballots]]. After the ballots are tabulated, it turns out Tracy has won by a single vote. Tracy's one vote margin of victory came about because Paul, feeling it would be dishonorable to vote for himself, voted for Tracy. During the ballot-counting verification, Jim observes Tracy dancing around gleefully in the hall — one of the student vote counters tipped her off that she won — and he secretly disposes of two of Tracy's ballots, declaring Paul the winner. When a janitor discovers the two discarded ballots in the trash and presents them to the principal, Jim is forced to resign. Jim's wife kicks him out of the house when he tries to apologize for what happened with Linda. Divorced and humiliated, Jim leaves Nebraska, choosing to fulfill his longtime dream of moving to [[New York City]], where he becomes a tour guide at the [[American Museum of Natural History]] and begins dating a new woman. Tracy gets accepted into [[Georgetown University]], while Paul gets into the [[University of Nebraska]]. Tammy finds a new girlfriend at her all-girls school. Jim encounters Tracy Flick one last time on a trip to Washington, D.C., during which he happens to see her get into a [[limousine]] with a male [[politician]]. Disgusted by the thought that Tracy's climb up the ladder of success is the result of her calculating and manipulative nature, Jim impulsively hurls a cup of soda at the limo before making a quick getaway. Jim later speaks to a group of elementary school students at the museum, refusing to respond to the raised hand of an overeager girl who reminds him of Tracy Flick. ==Cast== * [[Matthew Broderick]] as Jim McAllister * [[Reese Witherspoon]] as [[Tracy Flick|Tracy Enid Flick]] * [[Chris Klein (actor)|Chris Klein]] as Paul Metzler * [[Jessica Campbell]] as Tammy Metzler * [[Phil Reeves]] as Principal Walt Hendricks * [[Molly Hagan]] as Diane McAllister * [[Colleen Camp]] as Judith Flick * [[Nicholas D'Agosto]] as Larry Fouch * Jeanine Jackson as Jo Metzler * [[Holmes Osborne]] as Dick Metzler * [[Mark Harelik]] as Dave Novotny * Delaney Driscoll as Linda Novotny * [[Matt Malloy]] as Vice Principal Ron Ball * [[Frankie Ingrassia]] as Lisa Flanagan * Pegi Georgeson as Ballot Lady ==Production== Director Alexander Payne had become a fan of the novel by Tom Perrotta on which the film is based; the novel's rights were sold to Payne in January 1997. The novel was inspired by two key events. The first was the [[United States presidential election, 1992|1992 Bush vs. Clinton election campaign]], in which [[Ross Perot]] entered as a third party candidate (a move echoed by Tammy Metzler). The second was a 1992 incident at [[Memorial High School (Eau Claire, Wisconsin)|Memorial High School]] in [[Eau Claire, Wisconsin]], in which a pregnant student was elected homecoming queen, but staff announced a different winner and burned the ballots to cover it up.{{cite news| url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9E0CE3D71538F937A25753C1A964958260 | title=Officials Deny Pregnant Girl School Crown | work=The New York Times | date=October 14, 1992 | accessdate=May 1, 2010}}{{cite news | url=https://www.theguardian.com/books/2009/feb/21/tom-perrotta-interview | title=A life in writing: Tom Perrotta | work=The Guardian | location=London | first=John | last=Crace | date=February 21, 2009 | accessdate=May 1, 2010}} The film uses a number of stylized techniques in its storytelling, particularly through the use of freeze frames, flashbacks and voiceovers, which allow sections of the narrative to be delivered from the points of view of the four main characters.{{cite news | url=http://www.variety.com/review/VE1117492039.html?categoryid=31&cs=1&p=0 | title=Todd McCarthy Review from 'Variety' | date=April 19, 1999}} ==Reception== ''Election'' was a [[box office bomb]] as it grossed only $14.9 million against a budget of $25 million. The film, however, was met with critical acclaim. On [[Rotten Tomatoes]], the film holds a rating of 93%, based on 107 reviews, with an average rating of 7.8/10. The critical consensus reads, "''Election'' successfully combines dark humor and intelligent writing in this very witty and enjoyable film."{{rotten tomatoes|id=election}} On [[Metacritic]], the film has a score of 83 out of 100, based on 33 reviews, indicating "universal acclaim".{{metacritic film|id=election-1999}} [[Roger Ebert]] gave the film three and a half stars out of four, praising Witherspoon and Payne, and saying, "...here is a movie that is not simply about an obnoxious student, but also about an imperfect teacher, a lockstep administration, and a student body that is mostly just marking time until it can go out into the world and occupy valuable space".{{cite web | last=Ebert | first=Roger | url=http://www.rogerebert.com/reviews/election-1999 | title=Election Movie Review (1999) | work=RogerEbert.com | date=April 30, 1999 | accessdate=November 27, 2016}} ''Election'' is ranked #61 on [[Bravo (US TV channel)|Bravo's]] "100 Funniest Movies" and #9 on ''[[Entertainment Weekly]]'''s list of the "50 Best High School Movies", while Witherspoon's performance was ranked at #45 on the list of the "100 Greatest Film Performances of All Time" by ''[[Premiere (magazine)|Premiere]]''. According to Payne, it is also President [[Barack Obama]]'s favorite political film.{{cite web|quote=Barack Obama has told me twice that it’s his favorite political film.|last=Jacobs|first=Matthew|title=Pick Flick: An Oral History Of 'Election,' 15 Years Later|date=7 May 2014|publisher=''[[The Huffington Post]]''|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2014/05/07/election-oral-history_n_5248953.html|accessdate=26 October 2015}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{wikiquote}} * {{IMDb title|0126886|Election}} * {{Allmovie title|179426|Election}} * {{rotten tomatoes|id=election}} * {{metacritic film|id=election-1999}} * {{mojo title|election|Election}} {{Alexander Payne}} {{Independent Spirit Award for Best Film}} {{MTV Films}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Election}} [[Category:1999 films]] [[Category:1990s teen comedy films]] [[Category:1990s LGBT-related films]] [[Category:American black comedy films]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:American political satire films]] [[Category:English-language films]] [[Category:American LGBT-related films]] [[Category:Films about elections]] [[Category:Films about teacher–student relationships]] [[Category:Films based on American novels]] [[Category:Films directed by Alexander Payne]] [[Category:Films set in Nebraska]] [[Category:Films set in New York City]] [[Category:Films set in Washington, D.C.]] [[Category:Films shot in Washington, D.C.]] [[Category:Films shot in Nebraska]] [[Category:Films shot in Iowa]] [[Category:MTV Films films]] [[Category:Paramount Pictures films]] [[Category:American teen comedy films]] [[Category:Lesbian-related films]] [[Category:Films about educators]] [[Category:Independent Spirit Award for Best Film winners]] [[Category:LGBT-related comedy films]] [[Category:American high school films]] [[Category:1990s high school films]]

page.title: Five Bathing Women at a Lake

revision.text:
[[File:Y Lle Celf.JPG|thumb|250px|Y Lle Celf at the 2010 Eisteddfod in the basement of a steelworks in [[Blaenau Gwent]]]] The '''Gold Medal''' ([[Welsh language|Welsh]]: ''Medal Aur'') of the [[National Eisteddfod of Wales]] is awarded annually in three categories for excellence in [[Fine art|Fine Art]], [[Architecture]], or Craft and Design.<ref name=BBCblog2012>{{cite web|author=Chamberlain, Laura |title=2012 Eisteddfod: Gold medal round-up |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/blogs/wales/entries/cc474fae-1eff-3692-aef2-db4af1a660cb |publisher=[[BBC]] Blogs |date=7 August 2012 |accessdate=7 January 2015 }}</ref>
==Background== The National Eisteddfod of Wales is [[Wales]]' most important national cultural event, taking place annually. Its open exhibition of art and craft, ''[[Y Lle Celf]]'' ([[Welsh language|Welsh]]: 'The Art Space') is one of the highlights of the Welsh arts calendar.<ref name=goingforgold>{{cite web |title=Going for gold |work=|publisher=[[Western Mail (Wales)|Western Mail]] |url=http://www.thefreelibrary.com/Going+for+gold%3B+Wales+Millennium+Centre+is+counting+down+to+its+10th...-a0359460344 |date=17 January 2014 |accessdate=7 January 2015}}</ref> Gold medals are awarded in the [[Visual arts|Visual Arts]] section for outstanding contributions in different media: a Gold Medal for Fine Art has been awarded since 1951;<ref name=fineart>{{cite web |title=Gold Medal for Fine Art |url=http://www.eisteddfod.org.uk/english/about-us/our-history/winners/gold-medal-for-fine-art/ |publisher=The National Eisteddfod of Wales |accessdate=7 January 2015 }}</ref> a medal for Architecture has been offered since 1954 (though withheld and not awarded between 1954 and 1959);<ref name=architecture>{{cite web |title=Gold Medal for Architecture |url=http://www.eisteddfod.org.uk/english/about-us/our-history/winners/gold-medal-for-architecture/ |publisher=The National Eisteddfod of Wales |accessdate=7 January 2015 }}</ref> and a Gold Medal for Craft and Design has been awarded since 1985.<ref name=craftanddesign>{{cite web |title=Gold Medal for Craft and Design |url=http://www.eisteddfod.org.uk/english/about-us/our-history/winners/gold-medal-for-craft-and-design/ |publisher=The National Eisteddfod of Wales |accessdate=7 January 2015 }}</ref>
Other awards are the Tony Goble Award, given to a first time exhibitor, and the Josef Herman Award, chosen by the public<ref name=morais2014>{{cite web |author=Morais, Joao |title=Eisteddfod 2014: National Open Exhibition |url=http://www.walesartsreview.org/eisteddfod-2014-national-open-exhibition/ |work=Wales Arts Review|year=2014 |volume=3 |issue=16 |accessdate=20 January 2015 }}</ref> ([[Josef Herman]], a Polish emigree, won the Fine Art medal in 1962).<ref name=BBC2011>{{cite web |author=Chamberlain, Laura |title=Archbishop of Canterbury to present Eisteddfod art award |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/blogs/wales/posts/archbishop_of_canterbury_to_present_eisteddfod_art_award |work=BBC Wales |format=blog |date=26 July 2011|accessdate=20 January 2015 }}</ref>
The Architecture award was endowed by [[Thomas Alwyn Lloyd]] and is given in conjunction with the [[Design Commission for Wales]] and the [[Royal Society of Architects in Wales]], who advise the Eisteddfod judges.<ref name=BBCblog2012 />
The award is given to practitioners working in Wales, and a language rule has been in force since 1950 that any original words in art works must be in the [[Welsh language]].<ref name=BBCwindeterred>{{cite news|author=Thomas, Huw |title=Eisteddfod's Welsh language rule could deter artist Josephine Sowden |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-wales-25628182 |publisher=[[BBC News]] |date=7 January 2014 |accessdate=8 January 2015 }}</ref> In 2013 there was controversy when a [[Video art|video]] entirely in [[English language|English]] by England-born [[University of Wales, Newport|University of Wales Newport]] student Josephine Sowden was awarded the Fine Art medal.<ref name=WOwindeterred>{{cite news|author=Morgan, Sion |title=Eisteddfod winner deterred by festival's language policy |url=http://www.walesonline.co.uk/news/wales-news/eisteddfod-winner-deterred-festivals-language-6477961 |publisher=[[Wales Online]] |date=7 January 2014 |accessdate=7 January 2015 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Language row breaks out over Eisteddfod gold medal |url=http://www.itv.com/news/wales/update/2013-08-09/language-row-breaks-out-over-eisteddfod-gold-medal/ |publisher=[[ITV (TV network)|ITV News]] |date=9 August 2013 |accessdate=7 January 2015 }}</ref>
In January 2014 the [[Wales Millennium Centre]] (WMC) and [[Craft in the Bay]], [[Cardiff]] held an exhibition showcasing the work of previous winners of the Fine Art and the Craft awards.<ref name=goingforgold />
The 2014 Open Exhibition exhibited the work of 44 artists, selected from 300 entries.<ref name=morais2014 />
==Winners==
===Fine Art=== Source: [http://www.eisteddfod.org.uk/english/about-us/our-history/winners/gold-medal-for-fine-art/ The National Eisteddfod of Wales] {{columns-list|colwidth=30em| * 2014 – [[Sean Edwards (artist)|Sean Edwards]], for his video ''Maelfa'' of a shopping centre in [[Llanedeyrn]], Cardiff <ref name=morais2014 /> * 2013 – Josephine Sowden, for her video ''The Lilies of the Field'' <ref name=WOwindeterred /> * 2012 – [[Carwyn Evans]], for his installations based on agricultural machinery <ref name=BBCblog2012 /> * 2011 – [[Bedwyr Williams]], for his mixed media work including carved [[wellington boot]]s stuffed with straw <ref name=WObedwyr>{{cite news|url=http://www.walesonline.co.uk/news/local-news/bedwyrs-tribute-farmer-wins-gold-1813602 |title=Bedwyr’s tribute to the farmer wins the Gold Medal for Art at the Eisteddfod|work=Wales Online |date=1 August 2011| accessdate=20 January 2015}}</ref> * 2010 – [[Simon Fenoulhet]] * 2009 – [[Elfyn Lewis]] * 2008 – [[David Hastie]] * 2007 – [[Emrys Williams]], for his paintings of imaginary landscapes.<ref name=nocraftmedal>{{cite news |author=Clark, Rhodri |title=Judges decide not to award crafts gold medal |url=http://www.walesonline.co.uk/news/wales-news/judges-decide-not-award-crafts-2230017 |work=[[Wales Online]] |date=6 August 2007 |accessdate=11 January 2015 }}</ref> * 2006 – [[Aled Rhys Hughes]] * 2005 – [[Peter Finnemore]] * 2004 – Stuart Lee * 2003 – Tim Davies * 2002 – [[Ivor Davies (artist)|Ifor Davies]] * 2001 – [[Phil Nicol]] * 2000 – [[Sue Williams (artist)|Sue Williams]] * 1999 – Lois Williams * 1998 – Brendan Burns * 1997 – [[Iwan Bala]] * 1996 – ''No winner'' * 1995 – Paul Brewer * 1994 – Mary Griffiths * 1993 – Brendan Burns * 1992 – [[Shani Rhys James]] * 1991 – ''No winner'' * 1990 – Gareth Hugh Davies * 1989 – ''No winner'' * 1988 – Keith Roberts * 1987 – Keith Bowen * 1986 – [[Simon Callery]] * 1985 – Alistair Crawford * 1968–1984 – ''Medal not offered'' * 1967 – ''No winner'' * 1966 – Merlyn Evans * 1965 – ''No winner'' * 1964 – [[David Jones (artist-poet)|David Jones]] * 1963 – ''Medal not offered'' * 1962 – [[Josef Herman]] <ref name=BBC2011 /> * 1961 – [[Ceri Richards]] * 1959–1960 – ''Medal not offered'' * 1958 – Denys Short * 1957 – George Chapman * 1956 – John Elwyn * 1955 – D. C. Roberts * 1954 – Charles Burton * 1953 – [[Brenda Chamberlain (artist)|Brenda Chamberlain]] * 1952 – ''Medal not offered'' * 1951 – [[Brenda Chamberlain (artist)|Brenda Chamberlain]] }}
===Architecture=== * 2014 – [[Loyn & Co]] for 'Stormy Castle', a sustainable home on the [[Gower Peninsula]] <ref name=bdloyn>{{cite news|author=Hopkirk, Elizabeth |title=Loyn & Co wins Welsh Gold Medal |url=http://www.bdonline.co.uk/loyn-and-co-wins-welsh-gold-medal/5070130.article |work=Building Design |date=4 August 2014 |accessdate=7 January 2015}}</ref> * 2013 – John Pardey Architects for 'Trewarren', a house in [[Pembrokeshire]] <ref name=bdloyn /> * 2012 – [[HLM Architects]] for [[Archbishop McGrath Catholic High School]], [[Bridgend]] <ref name=bdloyn /> * 2011 – [[Ellis Williams Architects]] for [[Oriel Mostyn]], [[Llandudno]] <ref name=bdloyn /> * 2010 – ''Medal not awarded'' <ref name=bdloyn /> * 2009 – [[Ray Hole Architects]], for [[Hafod Eryri]] visitor centre, [[Snowdon]] <ref name=bdloyn /> * 2008 – [[Purcell (architects)|Purcell Miller Tritton]], for Blaenavon World Heritage Centre, [[Blaenavon]] <ref name=bdloyn /> * 2007 – Loyn & Co, for the Water Tower, [[Cyncoed]], Cardiff, breaking the normal tradition of making the award for a ''public'' building.<ref name=nocraftmedal /> * 2006 – [[Richard Rogers]], for the [[Senedd]], Cardiff <ref name=bdloyn /> * 2005 – [[Percy Thomas Partnership|Capita Percy Thomas]], Cardiff for the Wales Millennium Centre, Cardiff <ref>{{cite news|author=Price, Karen |title=The awards pile up for Wales' delightful 'armadillo' |url=http://www.thefreelibrary.com/The+awards+pile+up+for+Wales%27+delightful+%27armadillo%27.-a0134658283 |work=[[Western Mail (Wales)|Western Mail]] |date=30 July 2005 |accessdate=7 January 2015}}</ref>
===Craft and design=== Source: [http://www.eisteddfod.org.uk/english/about-us/our-history/winners/gold-medal-for-craft-and-design/ The National Eisteddfod of Wales] {{columns-list|colwidth=30em| * 2014 – Susan Phillips for her ceramic sculptures <ref>{{cite web| url = https://www.a-n.co.uk/news/national-eisteddfod-gold-medal-awards-in-visual-arts-announced| title= National Eisteddfod: Gold Medal awards in visual arts announced|publisher = a.n.| accessdate = 29 January 2015}}</ref> * 2013 – Josephine Sowden for her video ''The Lilies of the Field''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eisteddfod.org.uk/english/about-us/our-history/2013-archive/2013-news/?request=7461 |title=2013 News |publisher=The National Eisteddfod of Wales |accessdate=29 January 2015 }}{{dead link|date=January 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> * 2012 – Anne Gibbs, for her ceramic and found media assemblages <ref name=BBCblog2012 /> * 2011 – Peter Bodenham (Head of Ceramics at [[Coleg Sir Gâr]]) <ref name=WObedwyr /> * 2010 – Natalia Dias * 2009 – Lowri Davies * 2008 – Suzie Horan * 2007 – ''Medal not awarded'', "although the submission included work of quality, there was not enough of it."<ref name=nocraftmedal /> * 2006 – Carol Gwizdak * 2005 – Pamela Rawnsley * 2004 – Walter Keeler * 2003 – Mari Thomas * 2002 – ''No winner'' * 2001 – Claire Curneen * 2000 – Christine Jones * 1999 – David Binns * 1998 – Catrin Howell * 1997 – Marcelle Davies * 1996 – Steve Howlett * 1995 – Gavin Fraser Williams * 1994 – Marcus Thomas * 1993 – Ann Catrin Evans * 1992 – Cefyn Burgess * 1991 – Linda Roberts * 1990 – Morgen Hall * 1989 – ''No winner'' * 1988 – Jaqueline Jones * 1987 – Eleri Mills * 1986 – Gina Raby * 1985 – Martin Fraser (first winner)
Arts and Craft / Gelfyddyd a Chrefft * 1974 - Harry Meadows * 1976 - Harry Meadows }}
==References== {{reflist}}

revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=November 2013}} {{infobox person |name=Jane Murfin |image=Jane-Murfin-1923.jpg |caption=Jane Murfin in 1923 |birth_name=Jane Macklem |birth_date={{birth date|1884|10|27}} |birth_place=[[Quincy, Michigan]], United States |death_date={{death date and age|1955|08|10|1884|10|27}} |death_place=California, United States |occupation=Playwright, screenwriter, producer, director }} '''Jane Murfin''' (October 27, 1884 – August 10, 1955) was an American playwright and screenwriter. The author of several successful plays, she wrote some of them with actress [[Jane Cowl]]—most notably ''[[Smilin' Through (play)|Smilin' Through]]'' (1919), a sentimental fantasy that was adapted three times for motion pictures. In Hollywood Murfin became a popular screenwriter whose credits include ''[[What Price Hollywood?]]'' (1932), for which she received an Academy Award nomination. In the 1920s she wrote and produced films for her dog [[Strongheart]], the first major canine star. ==Life and career== [[File:Murfin-Strongheart-1923.jpg|thumb|left|Jane Murfin with [[Strongheart]] (1923)]] Jane Macklem was born October 27, 1884, in [[Quincy, Michigan]]. In 1907 she married attorney James Murfin, and retained his surname when the marriage ended fewer than five years later. Murfin began her career with the play ''Lilac Time'', which she co-wrote with actress [[Jane Cowl]]. The Broadway production opened February 6, 1917, and ran for 176 performances. Later that year the two women began collaborating, often under pseudonym Allan Langdon Martin, on a series of revivals of World War I melodramas.{{Cite web|url=https://wfpp.cdrs.columbia.edu/pioneer/ccp-jane-murfin/|title=Jane Murfin – Women Film Pioneers Project|website=wfpp.cdrs.columbia.edu|access-date=2016-10-04}} The pair later collaborated on ''Daybreak'', followed by ''Information Please'' (1918) and ''[[Smilin' Through (play)|Smilin' Through]]'' (1919). In Hollywood, Murfin became a leading screenwriter, writing many romantic comedies and dramas by herself or in collaboration.{{cite book|last=Katz |first=Ephraim |authorlink=Ephraim Katz |editor1-last=Klein |editor1-first=Fred |editor2-last=Nolen |editor2-first=Ronald Dean |title=The Film Encyclopedia|publisher=HarperPerennial |location=New York |year=1998 |edition=3rd|page=990 |isbn=0-06-273492-X}} [[File:Jane-Murfin-Directing-1924.jpg|thumb|right|260px|Murfin ordering the placement of lights on a film she is directing (1924)]] In 1920, director [[Laurence Trimble]] persuaded Murfin to purchase a [[German Shepherd]] dog—[[Strongheart]]—that became the first major canine film star.{{cite book |last=Trimble |first=Laurence |authorlink=Laurence Trimble |date=1926 |title=Strongheart; The Story of a Wonder Dog |location=Racine, Wis. |publisher=[[Whitman Publishing]] Company |oclc=4451141 }}{{cite news |last= |first= |date=February 10, 1954 |title=Laurence Trimble Dies |url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9B05E3DB1638E23BBC4852DFB466838F649EDE |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |access-date=2016-08-25 }}{{cite news |last= |first= |date=June 25, 1929 |title=Dog Hero of Films Dies |url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9805E2DF1130E33ABC4D51DFB0668382639EDE |newspaper=The New York Times |access-date=2016-08-25 }} Strongheart starred in four films that Trimble directed from Murfin's screenplays: ''The Silent Call'' (1921), ''[[Brawn of the North]]'' (1922), ''[[The Love Master (film)|The Love Master]]'' (1924) and ''White Fang'' (1925).{{cite web |url=http://www.afi.com/members/catalog/SearchResult.aspx?s=&TBL=PN&Type=CA&ID=4364 |title=Strongheart |website=AFI Catalog of Feature Films |publisher=American Film Institute |access-date=2016-08-24}} Murfin is credited with directing one film, ''Flapper Wives'' (1924),{{cite web |url=http://www.afi.com/members/catalog/AbbrView.aspx?s=&Movie=9093 |title=Flapper Wives |website=[[AFI Catalog of Feature Films]] |publisher=[[American Film Institute]] |access-date=2016-08-25}} before the dissolution of her partnership with Trimble. Film historian [[Kevin Brownlow]] described this partnership as both professional and personal; although some sources describe Trimble and Murfin as a husband-and-wife filmmaking team, no marriage has been substantiated.{{cite web |url=https://wfpp.cdrs.columbia.edu/pioneer/ccp-jane-murfin/ |title=Jane Murfin |last1=Buck |first1=Julie |last2= |first2= |date=September 27, 2013 |website=Women Film Pioneers Project |publisher=Center for Digital Research and Scholarship, [[Columbia University Libraries]] |access-date=2016-07-29}} Murfin's later screenwriting credits include ''[[Way Back Home (1931 film)|Way Back Home]]'' (1931), ''[[Our Betters]]'' (1933),{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/movie/review?res=9E02E0DE173BEF3ABC4C51DFB4668388629EDE|title=Constance Bennett, Violet Kemble-Cooper and Grant Mitchell in a Film of a Somerset Maugham Play|publisher=The New York Times|accessdate=March 17, 2012|date=February 24, 1933|author=[[Mordaunt Hall]]}} ''[[The Little Minister (1934 film)|The Little Minister]]'' (1934), ''[[Spitfire (1934 film)|Spitfire]]'' (1934), ''[[Roberta (1935 film)|Roberta]]'' (1935), ''[[Alice Adams (film)|Alice Adams]]'' (1935), ''[[The Women (1939 film)|The Women]]'' (1939), ''[[Pride and Prejudice (1940 film)|Pride and Prejudice]]'' (1940), and ''[[Dragon Seed (film)|Dragon Seed]]'' (1944). Murfin was married to director and actor [[Donald Crisp]] from 1932 until 1944. She is buried near Jane Cowl at [[Valhalla Memorial Park Cemetery]].[https://www.findagrave.com/memorial/5292 Jane Murfin at Find a Grave] == Personal life == Murfin was married first to lawyer James Murfin from 1907 to 1912. Her second marriage was to actor [[Donald Crisp]], for whom she would write parts in her scripts. ==Accolades== Murfin and [[Adela Rogers St. Johns]] were nominated for the [[5th Academy Awards|Academy Award]] for [[Academy Award for Best Story|Best Story]] for ''[[What Price Hollywood?]]'' (1932). [[Frances Marion]] received the award, for ''[[The Champ (1931 film)|The Champ]]''. ==Theatre credits== {| class="wikitable" |- ! Date ! Title ! Notes |- | February 6 – July 1917 | ''Lilac Time'' | [[New Victory Theatre|Theatre Republic]], New York City; written with [[Jane Cowl]]{{cite web |url=https://www.ibdb.com/broadway-cast-staff/jane-murfin-6650 |title=Jane Murfin |last1= |first1= |last2= |first2= |date= |website= |publisher=[[Internet Broadway Database]] |access-date=2016-08-25}}
Basis for the [[Lilac Time (1928 film)|1928 film]] |- | August 14 – October 1917 | ''Daybreak'' | [[Wallack's Theatre#254 West 42nd Street|Harris Theatre]], New York City; written with Jane Cowl
Basis for the [[Daybreak (1918 film)|1918 film]] |- | October 2 – November 1918 | ''Information Please'' | [[American Airlines Theatre|Selwyn Theatre]], New York City
Basis for the film ''A Temperamental Wife'' (1919) |- | December 30, 1919 – May 1920 | ''[[Smilin' Through (play)|Smilin' Through]]'' | [[Broadhurst Theatre]], New York City; written with Jane Cowl, as Allan Langdon Martin
Basis for film adaptations in [[Smilin' Through (1922 film)|1922]], [[Smilin' Through (1932 film)|1932]] and [[Smilin' Through (1941 film)|1941]] |- | October 21 – November 1929 | ''Stripped'' | [[Ambassador Theatre (New York City)|Ambassador Theatre]], New York City |} ==Select filmography== Murfin is credited as a writer; additional production credits are noted. {{multiple image | align = right | direction = vertical | width = 220 | image1 =Marie, Ltd (1919) - Ad 1.jpg | alt1 = | caption1 =Ad for ''Marie, Ltd.'' [[File:Beja tours 03.JPG|thumb|Overview]] The '''Kasbah of Béja''' is a historical citadel in the [[Tunisia]]n city [[Béja]], the [[Kasbah]] was built in the 2nd century BC and still exists till today which makes it one of oldest citadels in the region. == Location == The Kasbah was built on the top of a hill of 305 meters in northern Béja, and this site was chosen so the castle can overlook the city and its surrounding plains and countryside. == History == === The Kasbah during the antique and middle ages === The first citadel of Béja was built in 2nd century BC by the [[Carthaginians]], at that time Béja was called [[Vaga (Tunisia)|Vaga]] and was an important agriculture town so Carthage needed to protect specially from barbarian raids, but after the decline of the Carthaginian power, specially after the [[third Punic war]], the city fell under the influence of the [[Numidians]] and their king [[Jugurtha]] made the fortress his center of reign.
In 109 BC the [[Romans]] took power over the castle and then destroyed it. In 14 BC the Romans rebuilt the fort and improved it adding a garrison, walls and 22 towers.
The fort was once again razed to the ground this time by [[Vandals]] during the vandal invasion of North Africa, and the building only raised again by the [[Byzantine Empire|Byzantines]] after their liberation of the city from the Vandal rule, where the [[Byzantine emperors|Byzantine emperor]] [[Justinian I]] ordered in 533 Count Paulos to reconstruct the castle.
The expansion of the fort continued after the [[Muslim conquest of the Maghreb]] where the new Muslim rulers of the country gave it the name "Kasbah" and made it the official center of their representatives of the northern-region, the expansion continued during the rule of the [[Aghlabids]] but in 943 the Kasbah suffered major damage when Béja was sacked by the [[Kharijite]] rebels led by [[Abu Yazid]] and in 945 the kasbah was restored by the [[Fatimide]] Caliph [[Al-Mansur Billah]]. === The Kasbah during the modern era === [[File:Prise de Béja - 20-5-1881.jpg|thumb|right|Th fall of the Kasbah to the French troops]] In the 16th century, during the reign of [[Ahmad III (Hafsid)|Ahmed III]], the Kasbah was fortified by adding 14 canons to the fort.
The Ottomans too gave their part in the expansion of the citadel by establishing a [[flanking tower]] that protected the southern parts of the Kasbah and a garrison of the [[Janissary]], and in 1677 the Tunisian monarch [[Ali I Bey]] supported the garrison by a [[battalion]] of 500 knights from [[Spahis]].
After the [[French occupation of Tunisia]] in 1881, the Kasbah become a [[Gendarmerie]] barrack, and that from September 21, 1888 till the independence of the country in 1957. == Current use == After the independence of Tunisia from France, the fortress was turned into a cultural center, but today the Kasbah is in bad conditions. Restorations started in 2005 and directed by the Tunisian [[National Heritage Institute (Tunisia)|National Heritage Institute]], but it has stopped for lack of funding. == Gallery == File:Bejaaaa 01234 06.JPG| File:Murailles beja 01.jpg| File:Forteresse Béja007.jpg| File:Bejaaa123457123 09.JPG| File:Beja tours 07.JPG| ==References== {{Refbegin}} ''Research of Dr.Zouhair Ben Youssef''
''Abbé Neu, Notice historique sur la ville de Béja '' {{DEFAULTSORT:Kasbah of Beja}} [[Category:Béja]] [[Category:Buildings and structures completed in the 2nd century BC]] [[Category:Kasbahs in Tunisia]] [[Category:Ancient Roman architecture]] [[Category:Byzantine architecture]] [[Category:Islamic architecture]] [[Category:Castle architecture]]

revision.text:
{{Cleanup|date=February 2011}} {{Infobox book | italic title = | name = Knowing and the Known | image = Knowing and the Known - book cover.jpg | image_size = | caption = Hardcover edition | alt = | author = [[John Dewey]] and [[Arthur F. Bentley|Arthur Bentley]] | title_orig = | orig_lang_code = | title_working = | translator = | illustrator = | cover_artist = | country = United States | language = English | series = | subject = [[Epistemology]] | genre = Non-fiction | publisher = | published = 1949 | media_type = Print | pages = 334 pp. | awards = | isbn = 978-0837184982 | oclc = | dewey = | congress = | preceded_by = | followed_by = | wikisource = | exclude_cover = }} '''''Knowing and the Known''''' is a 1949 book by [[John Dewey]] and [[Arthur F. Bentley|Arthur Bentley]].
== Overview == As well as a Preface, an Introduction and an Index, the book consists of 12 chapters, or papers, as the authors call them in their introduction.<ref name=KnowingKnown>{{cite book|last1=Dewey|first1=John|title=Knowing and the Known|date=1976|publisher=Praeger|url=https://www.aier.org/sites/default/files/Files/Documents/Standard/KnowingKnownFullText.pdf|accessdate=4 December 2014}}</ref> Chapters 1 (Vagueness in Logic), 8 (Logic in an Age of Science) and 9 (A Confused "Semiotic") were written by Bentley; Chapter 10 (Common Sense and Science) by Dewey, while the remainder were signed jointly.
The terminology problem in the fields of [[epistemology]] and [[logic]] is partially due, according to Dewey and Bentley,<ref>John Dewey, [[Arthur F. Bentley|Arthur Bentley]], (1949). ''Knowing and the Known''. Beacon Press, [[Boston, Massachusetts|Boston]].</ref> to inefficient and imprecise use of words and concepts that reflect three historic levels of organization and presentation.<ref>John Dewey, [[Arthur F. Bentley|Arthur Bentley]], (1949). ''Knowing and the Known''. Beacon Press, [[Boston, Massachusetts|Boston]]. p107-109</ref> In the order of chronological appearance, these are :
*'''Self-Action''': Prescientific concepts regarded humans, animals, and things as possessing powers of their own which initiated or caused their actions. *'''Interaction''': as described by [[Isaac Newton|Newton]], where things, living and inorganic, are balanced against something in a system of interaction, for example, [[Newton's laws of motion|the third law of motion]] states that for every action there is an equal and opposite reaction. *'''Transaction''': where modern systems of descriptions and naming are employed to deal with multiple aspects and phases of action without any attribution to ultimate, final, or independent entities, essences, or realities.
==Chapters== #Vagueness in Logic #The Terminological Problem #Postulations #Interaction and Transaction #Transactions as Known and Named #Specification #The Case of Definition #Logic in an Age of Science #A Confused "Semiotic" #Common Sense and Science #A Trial Group of Names #Summary of Progress Made *Appendix: A Letter from John Dewey
==Transactions== A series of characterizations of Transactions indicate the wide range of considerations involved.<ref>John Dewey, [[Arthur F. Bentley|Arthur Bentley]], (1949). ''Knowing and the Known''. Beacon Press, [[Boston, Massachusetts|Boston]]. p121-139</ref>
*Transaction is inquiry in which existing descriptions of events are accepted only as tentative and preliminary. New descriptions of the aspects and phases of events based on inquiry may be made at any time. *Transaction is inquiry characterized by primary observation that may range across all subject matters that present themselves, and may proceed with freedom to re-determine and rename the objects comprised in the system. *Transaction is Fact such that no one of the constituents can be adequately specified as apart from the specification of all the other constituents of the full subject matter. *Transaction develops and widens the phases of knowledge, and broadens the system within the limits of observation and report. *Transaction regards the extension in time to be comparable to the extension in space, so that “thing” is in action, and “action” is observable in things. *Transaction assumes no pre-knowledge of either organism or environment alone as adequate, but requires their primary acceptance in a common system. *Transaction is the procedure which observes men talking and writing, using language and other representational activities to present their perceptions and manipulations. This permits a full treatment, descriptive and functional, of the whole process inclusive of all its contents, and with the newer techniques of inquiry required. *Transactional Observation insists on the right to freely proceed to investigate any subject matter in whatever way seems appropriate, under reasonable hypothesis.
Illustration of differences between self-action, interaction, and transaction, as well as the different facets of transactional inquiry are provided by statements of positions that Dewey and Bentley definitely did ''not'' hold and which ''never should be read'' into their work.<ref>John Dewey, [[Arthur F. Bentley|Arthur Bentley]], (1949). ''Knowing and the Known''. Beacon Press, [[Boston, Massachusetts|Boston]]. p119-121</ref>
# They do not use any basic differentiation of subject vs. object; of soul vs. body; of mind vs. matter; or self vs. nonself. # They do not support the introduction of any ultimate knower from a different or superior realm to account for what is known. # Similarly, they do not tolerate "entities" or "realities" of any kind intruding as if from behind or beyond the knowing-known events, with power to interfere. # They exclude the introduction of "faculties" or other "operators" of an organism’s behaviors, and require for all investigations the direct observation and contemporaneous report of findings and results. # Especially, they recognize no names that are offered as expressions of “inner” thoughts, nor of names that reflect compulsions by outer objects. # They reject imaginary words and terms said to lie between the organism and its environmental objects, and require the direct location and source for all observations relevant to the investigation. # They tolerate no meanings offered as "ultimate" truth or "absolute" knowledge. # Since they are concerned with what is inquired into, and the process of knowings, they have no interest in any underpinning. Any statement that is or can be made about a knower, self, mind, or subject, or about a known thing, an object, or a cosmos must be made on the basis of, and in the language applicable to the specific investigation.
In summary, all of human knowledge consists of actions and products of acts in which men and women participate with other human beings, with animals and plants, as well as objects of all types, in any environment. Men and women have, are, and will present their acts of knowing and known in language. Generic people, and specific men and women, are known to be vulnerable to error. Consequently, all knowledge (knowing and known) whether commonsensical or scientific; past, present, or future; is subject to further inquiry, examination, review, and revision.
== See also == * [[List of publications by John Dewey]] * [[Transactionalism]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[https://www.aier.org/sites/default/files/Files/Documents/Standard/KnowingKnownFullText.pdf American Institute for Economic Research for full copy in PDF format] *(with Arthur Bentley) [https://www.aier.org/sites/default/files/Files/Documents/Standard/KnowingKnownFullText.pdf Full copy in pdf file available from the American Institute for Economic Research]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Knowing and the Known}} [[Category:1949 books]] [[Category:Contemporary philosophical literature]] [[Category:Epistemology literature]] [[Category:Logic literature]] [[Category:Philosophy books]] [[Category:Works by John Dewey]] [[Category:Beacon Press books]]

revision.text:
The '''Lindo lamp''' is a [[silver]] [[Menorah (Hanukkah)|Chanukah menorah]]. It is the oldest known example of a Chanukah menorah made in Britain.<ref> {{cite web |url=http://search.hlf.org.uk/NHMFWeb/LatestNews/Jewish+Museum+Closer+to+Saving+Silver+Hanukah+Lamp.htm |title=Jewish Museum Closer to Saving Silver Hanukah Lamp — National Heritage Memorial Fund |publisher=search.hlf.org.uk |accessdate=2009-07-31 |last= |first= }} </ref>
==History==
The lamp was created by London silversmith John Ruslen in 1709.<ref> {{cite web |url = http://www.thejewishmuseum.org/onlinecollection/object_collection.php?objectid=17436&lefttxt=ruslen |title = The Jewish Museum — Presentation tray |publisher = www.thejewishmuseum.org |accessdate = 2009-07-31 |last = |first = |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://archive.is/20130415222914/http://www.thejewishmuseum.org/onlinecollection/object_collection.php?objectid=17436&lefttxt=ruslen |archivedate = 2013-04-15 |df = }} </ref> It was commissioned to celebrate the marriage of Elias Lindo and Rachel Lopes Ferreira.<ref name="ad"> {{cite web |url=http://artdaily.org/index.asp?int_sec=2&int_new=32217 |title=Artdaily.org — The First Art Newspaper on the Net |publisher=artdaily.org |accessdate=2009-07-31 |last= |first= }} </ref> The couple were married at London's [[Bevis Marks Synagogue]] on February 2, 1708–09<!-- Huh? -->.<ref>Transactions of the Jewish Historical Society of England, Hanson & co., 1958, v. 18–19, p. 117.</ref>
The lamp has been on loan to the [[London Jewish Museum]], which has displayed it for 77 years, since the day the museum opened in 1932.<ref name="jp"> {{cite web |url=http://wwwtmp-origin.jpost.com/servlet/Satellite?pagename=JPost%2FJPArticle%2FShowFull&cid=1246443871704 |title=London's Jewish Museum preparing to buy 300-year-old hanukkia for new location |publisher=pqasb.pqarchiver.com |accessdate=2009-07-31 |last= |first= }} </ref> The lamp is considered to be among the most important objects in the museum's collection.<ref name="ad" /> It is feared that if sufficient funds cannot be raised to purchase the lamp, it will be purchased by a private collector and disappear from public view.<ref name="jp" /> If the Museum, which is undergoing a major renovation, manages to raise sufficient funds to purchase the menorah, it will be on view in a new gallery entitled "Judaism: A Living Faith", designed to display the museum's "magnificent" collection of Jewish ceremonial art. The Museum's collection of ceremonial art has been awarded "designated" status by the Museums, Libraries and Archives Council in recognition of its outstanding national importance.<ref name="jp" />
In 2009 the family that has long loaned the lamp to the Museum announced that it wished to sell the lamp, a price of £300,000 was set should the Museum wish to purchase the lamp.<ref name="jp" /> The [[National Heritage Memorial Fund]] (NHMF) agreed to contribute £145,000. The Art Fund offered to contribute £75,000 and the MLA /V&A Purchase Fund £30,000, if the Museum can raise the remaining £50,000 from private donors.<ref name="ad" /><ref name="jp" /><ref name="Samuel Gruber's Jewish Art"/>
==Art== [[File:Abraham Bloemaert - Landscape with the Prophet Elijah in the Desert - WGA2277.jpg|thumb|right|220px|Landscape with the Prophet [[Elijah]] in the Desert, [[Hermitage Museum]]]]
The [[sterling silver]] menorah is chased with a relief image of the Prophet [[Elijah]] fed by [[raven]]s, a scene from the [[Books of Kings|Book of Kings]] (I Kings 17:6). It is common for Jewish ceremonial artistic objects to depict a biblical character bearing the same name as the patron who commissioned an object, in this case Elias (Elijah) Lindo. The subject is not very common in Jewish art, but it was popular in the Baroque period in both Catholic and Protestant lands.<ref name="Samuel Gruber's Jewish Art"> {{cite web |url=http://samgrubersjewishartmonuments.blogspot.com/2009/07/uk-london-jewish-museum-must-purchase.html |title=Samuel Gruber's Jewish Art & Monuments: UK: London Jewish Museum Must Purchase Lindo Hanukkiah on Display for 70 Years |publisher=samgrubersjewishartmonuments.blogspot.com |accessdate=2009-07-31 |last= |first= }} </ref> A well-known ''Elijah fed by Ravens'' painted in 1620 by [[Guercino]] hangs in the [[National Gallery]].<ref> {{cite web |url=http://www.nationalgallery.org.uk/paintings/guercino-elijah-fed-by-ravens |title=Guercino – Elijah fed by Ravens – L273 |publisher=The National Gallery, London |accessdate=2009-07-31 |last= |first= }} </ref> A version by [[Abraham Bloemaert]] is owned by the [[Cleveland Museum of Art]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.clevelandart.org/explore/artistwork.asp?creatorid=881&recNo=0&woRecNo=4 |title=Cleveland Museum of Art — Elijah in the Wilderness Fed by Ravens (Abraham Bloemaert) |publisher=www.clevelandart.org |accessdate=2009-07-31 |last= |first= |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070228134737/http://www.clevelandart.org/Explore/artistwork.asp?creatorid=881&recNo=0&woRecNo=4 |archivedate=February 28, 2007 }} </ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:Jewish ceremonial art]] [[Category:Jewish English history]] [[Category:Silver objects]]

{{DISPLAYTITLE:List of ''Nepenthes'' literature}} [[File:Nepenthesbongso.jpg|thumb|A hand-coloured lithograph of ''[[Nepenthes bongso|N. bongso]]'' from [[Pieter Willem Korthals]]'s "[[Over het geslacht Nepenthes|Over het geslacht ''Nepenthes'']]" of 1839, generally regarded as the first monograph on the genus.Clarke, C.M. 1997. ''[[Nepenthes of Borneo]]''. Natural History Publications (Borneo), Kota Kinabalu.Phillipps, A., A. Lamb & C.C. Lee 2008. ''[[Pitcher Plants of Borneo]]''. Second Edition. Natural History Publications (Borneo), Kota Kinabalu.]] This '''list of ''Nepenthes'' literature''' is a listing of major published works dealing with the tropical [[pitcher plant]]s of the [[genus]] ''[[Nepenthes]]''. It includes specialised standalone publications and [[Biological classification|taxonomic]] [[monograph]]s released as part of larger works, but excludes regular [[academic journal|journal]] and [[magazine]] articles. Unless otherwise indicated, all information on individual publications is sourced from them directly. Works are listed chronologically by year of first publication. __TOC__ {{-}} ==Standalone publications== This list includes all works published as standalone [[book]]s or booklets, with the exception of [[children's literature]], which is listed separately [[#Children's literature|below]]. {| class="sortable wikitable" ! Name !! Author(s) !! Year !! Language !! Publisher !! Pages !! Additional information !! Reviews |- | {{nihongo|''History of Nepenthes''
|ウツボカヅラの歴史|Utsubokadzura no rekishi}}[http://www.honda-e.com/A05_CP%20Book%20Library/CPBooks_Large/CPBook_NepenKusakabe.htm History of Nepenthes]. Carnivorous Plants / Insectivorous Plants in the Wilderness. || [[Isamu Kusakabe]] || 1961 || [[Japanese language|Japanese]] || [[Insectivorous Plant Society]] || 54 || special issue no. 3 of the ''[[Journal of Insectivorous Plant Society]]'' || |- | ''[[Nepenthes of Mount Kinabalu]]'' || [[Shigeo Kurata]] || 1976 || English || [[Sabah National Parks Trustees]] || 80 || significantly contributed to popular interest in ''Nepenthes''Shivas, R.G. 1984. ''Pitcher Plants of Peninsular Malaysia & Singapore''. Maruzen Asia, Kuala Lumpur. || see [[Nepenthes of Mount Kinabalu|article]] |- | ''The Pitcher Plant: Nepenthes khasiana'' || [[Renu Prova Momin Bordoloi]] || 1977 || English || Dutta Baruah || 59 || part of the ''Carnivorous Plants of North East India'' series; 5 pages of plates not included in page count || |- | ''Pitcher Plants of Peninsular Malaysia & Singapore'' || [[Roger Shivas]] || 1984 || English || Maruzen Asia || xii + 58 || 24 pages of plates not included in page count || "It was the author's intention to make this book serve as a field guide and he succeeded in this by giving us good closeup pictures of upper, lower and sometimes intermediate pitchers of all 12 species that are described. Although the book is small, and ideal for field use, it does not lack any of the essential information that one needs to use in finding these plants and admiring them."[Anonymous] 1984. Book review. ''[[Carnivorous Plant Newsletter]]'' '''13'''(2): 54. |- | {{nihongo|''The Grief Vanishing – Nepenthes''[http://www.sarracenia.com/faq/faq6010a.html Ivo's Book List]. The Carnivorous Plant FAQ. ([http://ivo.koudela.sweb.cz/books.txt updated list])
|無憂草 – Nepenthes|Muyū kusa – Nepenthes}} || [[Tetsuya Oikawa]] || 1992 || [[Japanese language|Japanese]] || Parco Co. || 66 || part of the ''Jungle Books'' series || "1 to 9 photos of each mentioned species, information on morphology and functions of ''Nepenthes''. The photos are so beautiful that at least ''Nepenthes'' enthusiasts should have this book." |- | ''[[Pitcher-Plants of Borneo]]'' || [[Anthea Phillipps]] & [[Anthony Lamb]] || 1996 || English || [[Natural History Publications (Borneo)]] || x + 171 || strongly focused on botanical and horticultural history; mainly illustrated with watercolour paintings by Susan M. Phillipps || see [[Pitcher-Plants of Borneo|article]] |- | ''[[Nepenthes of Borneo]]'' || [[Charles Clarke (botanist)|Charles Clarke]] || 1997, 2006
(reprint) || English || [[Natural History Publications (Borneo)]] || xii + 207 || ecological and taxonomic monograph || see [[Nepenthes of Borneo|article]] |- | ''[[Nepenthes of Sumatra and Peninsular Malaysia]]'' || [[Charles Clarke (botanist)|Charles Clarke]] || 2001 || English || [[Natural History Publications (Borneo)]] || x + 326 || ecological and taxonomic monograph; 1 new species described || see [[Nepenthes of Sumatra and Peninsular Malaysia|article]] |- | ''A Guide to the Pitcher Plants of Sabah'' || [[Charles Clarke (botanist)|Charles Clarke]] || 2001 || English || [[Natural History Publications (Borneo)]] || iv + 40 || field guide || "The photos are simply incredible, and the book covers important information such as natural habitats. Indeed, it is somewhat like a condensed version of "''Nepenthes'' of Borneo", but rewritten in less scientific language."Catalani, M. 2003. Book review. ''[[Carnivorous Plant Newsletter]]'' '''32'''(1): 10. |- | ''A Guide to the Pitcher Plants of Peninsular Malaysia'' || [[Charles Clarke (botanist)|Charles Clarke]] || 2002 || English || [[Natural History Publications (Borneo)]] || iv + 32 || field guide || "As usual for one of Clarke's books, the text is concise, well written and accurate. But overshadowing the text is the photography, which is truly beautiful as well as illustrative of the essential characters of each species and hybrid."Rice, B. 2003. Book review. ''[[Carnivorous Plant Newsletter]]'' '''32'''(4): 112. |- | ''Borneo: Its Mountains and Lowlands with their Pitcher Plants'' || [[Hugo Steiner]] || 2002 || English || Toihaan Publishing Company || viii + 136 || mainly illustrated with photographs taken by the author between 1992 and 2002 || "People looking for an interesting but not too technical or scientific work on Borneo and its pitcher plants would especially benefit from this book. [...] The aesthetic aspect remains very good despite two or three low quality photographs [...]"Hartmeyer, S.R.H. 2003. Book review. ''[[Carnivorous Plant Newsletter]]'' '''32'''(3): 68.{{de icon}} Hartmeyer, S.R.H. 2003. Ein neues Buch zum Thema ''Nepenthes'' in englischer Sprache. ''[[Das Taublatt]]'' '''47'''(3): 22–23. |- | ''Pitcher Plants of Sarawak'' || [[Charles Clarke (botanist)|Charles Clarke]] & [[Ch'ien Lee]] || 2004 || English || [[Natural History Publications (Borneo)]] || vi + 81 || pocket field guide; mainly illustrated with photographs by [[Ch'ien Lee]] || "This is a wonderful introduction to the species that grow in this area and is in full colour. With an introduction to ''Nepenthes'', the 25 species plus an environmental examination it whets your appetite to want to visit this area or at least grow the plants."[Anonymous] 2005. {{cite web |url= http://www.vcps.au.com/journals/75_Mar_2005Public.pdf |title= A new ''Nepenthes'' book. |deadurl= yes |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110707185305/http://www.vcps.au.com/journals/75_Mar_2005Public.pdf |archivedate= 2011-07-07 |df= }} ''[[Victorian Carnivorous Plant Society Journal]]'' '''75''': 18.
"As usual with Clarke's books, the photographs are excellent." |- | ''[[The Nepenthaceae of the Netherlands Indies]]'' || [[B. H. Danser]] || 2006 || English || [[Natural History Publications (Borneo)]] || vi + 206 || reprint of the 1928 monograph; includes 15-page introduction by [[Charles Clarke (botanist)|Charles Clarke]]Clarke, C.M. 2006. Introduction. In: Danser, B.H. ''[[The Nepenthaceae of the Netherlands Indies]]''. Natural History Publications (Borneo), Kota Kinabalu. pp. 1–15. || see [[The Nepenthaceae of the Netherlands Indies|article]] |- | ''A Field Guide to the Nepenthes of Sumatra'' || [[Hernawati]] & [[Pitra Akhriadi]] || 2006 || English || PILI-NGO Movement || xiv + 94 || field guide; result of research program funded by [[BP]] || "[...] a short book presenting basic information on thirty-one Sumatran taxa [...] The quality of the paper, printing and images is perhaps a little low, but given the very meagre funds available to produce this book, this is understandable."Clarke, C. 2007. Book review. ''[[Carnivorous Plant Newsletter]]'' '''36'''(3): 72. |- | ''Nepenthes: Kantong Semar Yang Unik'' || [[Muhammad Mansur]] || 2006 || [[Indonesian language|Indonesian]] || Penebar Swadaya || iv + 100 || || |- | ''Petunjuk Praktis Perawatan Nepenthes''[http://perpuskabpkl.com/index.php?p=show_detail&id=3913 Petunjuk Praktis Perawatan Nepenthes] {{webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20130828005517/http://perpuskabpkl.com/index.php?p=show_detail&id=3913 |date=2013-08-28 }}. Google Books. || [[Arie Wijayani Purwanto]] || 2007 || [[Indonesian language|Indonesian]] || Kanisius || 60 || cultivation guide || |- | ''Entuyut (Nepenthes) asal Kalimantan Barat''{{id icon}} [http://www.kalbariana.net/entuyut-nepenthes-asal-kalimantan-barat Entuyut (Nepenthes) asal Kalimantan Barat] {{webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20130827030627/http://www.kalbariana.net/entuyut-nepenthes-asal-kalimantan-barat |date=2013-08-27 }}. Perpustakaan Deposit Kalimantan Barat. || [[Agustina Listiawati]] & [[Chairani Siregar]] || 2008 || [[Indonesian language|Indonesian]] || Untan Press || 88 || government publication || |- | ''[[Pitcher Plants of Borneo]]'', Second Edition || [[Anthea Phillipps]], [[Anthony Lamb]] & [[Ch'ien Lee]] || 2008 || English || [[Natural History Publications (Borneo)]] || viii + 298 || much expanded second edition; strongly focused on botanical and horticultural history; includes many photographs by [[Ch'ien Lee]] || see [[Pitcher Plants of Borneo|article]] |- | {{lang|th|ร้อยพรรณพฤกษา ไม้กินแมลง หม้อข้าวหม้อแกงลิง}} || [[Suwarun Suphawut]] || 2009{{Ref_label|A|a|none}} || [[Thai language|Thai]] || เศรษฐศิลป์ || 112 || strongly focused on cultivation and horticultural hybrids || |- | ''[[Pitcher Plants of the Old World]]'' (2 volumes) || [[Stewart McPherson (geographer)|Stewart McPherson]] || 2009 || English || Redfern Natural History Productions || xvi + 1399 || also covers ''[[Cephalotus|Cephalotus follicularis]]''; 1 new species described || see [[Pitcher Plants of the Old World|article]] |- | ''The Malaysian Nepenthes: Evolutionary and Taxonomic Perspectives'' || [[Chris Thorogood]] || 2010 || English || Nova Science Publishers || vi + 158 || part of the ''Botanical Research and Practices Series'' || |- | ''Nepenthes della Thailandia: Diario di viaggio'' || [[Marcello Catalano]] || 2010 || [[Italian language|Italian]] || self-published || 207 || travel diary; 4 new species described || "In a narrative style that only Italians master (“se non è vero, è ben trovato”), the author describes his remarkable experience from roughly a decade of training and research both at herbaria and in the field. [...] The diversity of the genus in Thailand as featured in the present book is far greater than expressed by any previous author."Schlauer, J. 2010. Book review. ''[[Carnivorous Plant Newsletter]]'' '''39'''(2): 61. |- | ''Field Guide to the Pitcher Plants of the Philippines'' || [[Stewart McPherson (geographer)|Stewart McPherson]] & [[Victor B. Amoroso]] || 2011 || English || Redfern Natural History Productions || 61 || field guide[Anonymous] 2012. VCPS News: three new ''Nepenthes'' books. ''[[Victorian Carnivorous Plant Society Journal]]'' '''103''': 5. || |- | ''[[New Nepenthes: Volume One]]'' || [[Stewart McPherson (geographer)|Stewart McPherson]] || 2011 || English || Redfern Natural History Productions || xiv + 595 || 7 new species described; includes accounts of new discoveries since 2009 publication of ''[[Pitcher Plants of the Old World]]'' || |- | ''Field Guide to the Pitcher Plants of Sulawesi'' || [[Stewart McPherson (geographer)|Stewart McPherson]] & [[Alastair Robinson]] || 2012 || English || Redfern Natural History Productions || 49 || field guide || |- | ''Field Guide to the Pitcher Plants of Borneo'' || [[Stewart McPherson (geographer)|Stewart McPherson]] & [[Alastair Robinson]] || 2012 || English || Redfern Natural History Productions || 101 || field guide || |- | ''Field Guide to the Pitcher Plants of Australia and New Guinea'' || [[Stewart McPherson (geographer)|Stewart McPherson]] & [[Alastair Robinson]] || 2012 || English || Redfern Natural History Productions || 59 || field guide || |- | ''Field Guide to the Pitcher Plants of Peninsular Malaysia and Indochina'' || [[Stewart McPherson (geographer)|Stewart McPherson]] & [[Alastair Robinson]] || 2012 || English || Redfern Natural History Productions || 59 || field guide || |- | ''Field Guide to the Pitcher Plants of Sumatra and Java'' || [[Stewart McPherson (geographer)|Stewart McPherson]] & [[Alastair Robinson]] || 2012 || English || Redfern Natural History Productions || 91 || field guide || |- | ''Kantong Semar Mirabilis (Nepenthes mirabilis Druce) dan Teknik Budidayanya''[http://perpustakaan.krbogor.lipi.go.id/digilib_krb/index.php?p=show_detail&id=1427 Kantong Semar Mirabilis (Nepenthes mirabilis Druce) dan Teknik Budidayanya]{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}. Digital Library - Bogor Botanic Gardens. || [[Tri Handayani]], [[Yupi Isnaini]] & [[Yuzammi]] || 2012 || [[Indonesian language|Indonesian]] || Pusat Konservasi Tumbuhan Kebun Raya Bogor - LIPI || iii + 77 || part of the ''Pendayagunaan Tumbuhan Berpotensi'' series (no. 1) || |- | ''Mengenal Kantong Semar Adrianii''[http://perpustakaan.krbogor.lipi.go.id/digilib_krb/index.php?p=show_detail&id=1395 Mengenal Kantong Semar Adrianii]{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}. Digital Library - Bogor Botanic Gardens. || [[Tri Handayani]], [[Hartutiningsih-M. Siregar]], [[Melani Kurnia Rismawati]] & [[Hary Wawangningrum]] || 2012 || [[Indonesian language|Indonesian]] || Pusat Konservasi Tumbuhan Kebun Raya Bogor - LIPI || v + 54 || part of the ''Pendayagunaan Tumbuhan Berpotensi'' series (no. 4) || |} ==Monographs published as part of larger works== This list includes major monographs that were ''not'' released as standalone publications. In the case of journal articles and papers, the parent publication is indicated in brackets. Only the primary [[prose|prosaic]] language is listed for each publication, although many of the earlier monographs also include substantial portions of [[Latin]] text in the form of taxon descriptions. Some of the taxa [[Species description|formally described]] in these monographs are not considered taxonomically valid today. {| class="sortable wikitable" ! Name !! Author(s) !! Year !! Language !! Format !! Pages !! Additional information !! Reviews |- | "[[Over het geslacht Nepenthes|Over het geslacht ''Nepenthes'']]" || [[Pieter Willem Korthals]] || 1839 || [[Dutch language|Dutch]] || part of ''Verhandelingen over de Natuurlijke Geschiedenis der Nederlandsche overzeesche bezittingen'' || 44 || generally regarded as the first monograph on ''Nepenthes''; 3 new species described || |- | "Über die Gattung ''Nepenthes'' besonders in Rücksicht auf ihre physiologische Eigenthümlichkeit" || [[Ernst Wunschmann]] || 1872 || [[German language|German]] || doctoral thesis ([[Humboldt University of Berlin|Friedrich-Wilhelms-Universität Berlin]]); published by Buchdruckerei von Gustav Schade (Otto Francke) || 50 || sometimes considered the first monograph on ''Nepenthes'' || |- | "[[Nepenthaceae (1873 monograph)|Nepenthaceae]]" || [[Joseph Dalton Hooker]] || 1873 || [[Latin]] || part of the seventeenth volume of ''[[Prodromus Systematis Naturalis Regni Vegetabilis]]'' || 16 || 7 new species described; primarily focused on new discoveries from northern Borneo || |- | "[[Die Gattung Nepenthes|Die Gattung ''Nepenthes'']]" || [[Günther Beck von Mannagetta und Lerchenau]] || 1895 || [[German language|German]] || journal article (''Wiener Illustrirte Garten-Zeitung'') || 46 || published in 4 parts; 4 new species described; 1 new species combination || |- | "[[Nepenthaceae (1908 monograph)|Nepenthaceae]]" || [[John Muirhead Macfarlane]] || 1908 || English || part of ''[[Das Pflanzenreich]]'' || 91 || 8 new species described; includes detailed accounts of structure, anatomy, and development || see [[Nepenthaceae (1908 monograph)|article]] |- | "[[The Nepenthaceae of the Netherlands Indies]]" || [[B. H. Danser]] || 1928 || English || journal article (''Bulletin du Jardin Botanique de Buitenzorg'') || 190 || widely considered the most important monograph on ''Nepenthes'';McPherson, S.R. 2009. ''[[Pitcher Plants of the Old World]]''. 2 volumes. Redfern Natural History Productions, Poole.Clarke, C.M. 2001. ''[[Nepenthes of Sumatra and Peninsular Malaysia]]''. Natural History Publications (Borneo), Kota Kinabalu. 17 new species described || see [[The Nepenthaceae of the Netherlands Indies|article]] |- | "Nepenthaceae" || [[Hermann Harms]] || 1936 || [[German language|German]] || part of ''Die natürlichen Pflanzenfamilien'' || 38 || similar to Danser's treatment || |- | "''Nepenthes'' di Sumatera: The genus ''Nepenthes'' of the Sumatra Island" || [[Rusjdi Tamin]] & [[Mitsuru Hotta]] || 1986 || [[Indonesian language|Indonesian]] || paper (''Diversity and Dynamics of Plant Life in Sumatra'', Part 1) || 35 || 3 new species described (originally ''[[nomen nudum|nomina nuda]]'' as they were published without Latin diagnoses) || |- | "Pitcher-plants of East Malaysia and Brunei" || [[Anthea Phillipps]] & [[Anthony Lamb]] || 1988 || English || journal article (''Nature Malaysiana'') || 20 || includes 80 colour photographs || |- | "[[An account of Nepenthes in New Guinea|An account of ''Nepenthes'' in New Guinea]]" || [[Matthew Jebb]] || 1991 || English || journal article (''Science in New Guinea'') || 48 || includes a survey of pitcher prey assemblages || see [[An account of Nepenthes in New Guinea|article]] |- | "[[A skeletal revision of Nepenthes (Nepenthaceae)|A skeletal revision of ''Nepenthes'' (Nepenthaceae)]]" || [[Matthew Jebb]] & [[Martin Cheek]] || 1997 || English || journal article (''[[Blumea (journal)|Blumea]]'') || 106 || 6 new species described; 1 new species combination || see [[A skeletal revision of Nepenthes (Nepenthaceae)|article]] |- | "[[Nepenthaceae (2001 monograph)|Nepenthaceae]]" || [[Martin Cheek]] & [[Matthew Jebb]] || 2001 || English || fifteenth volume of ''[[Flora Malesiana]]'' || iv + 157 || only covers species native to [[Malesia]] || see [[Nepenthaceae (2001 monograph)|article]] |} ==Children's literature== {| class="sortable wikitable" ! Name !! Author(s) !! Year !! Language !! Publisher !! Pages !! Additional information !! Reviews |- | ''Jack & the Carnivorous Pitcher Plant'' || [[Tan Wee Kiat]] & [[Amy Sabrielo]] || 1999 || English || Landmark Books || 83 || illustrated by Lesley Gan; dust jacket folds out into a ''Nepenthes''-themed board game || |- | ''Singapore Heritage: the Raffles Pitcher Plant'' || [[Tan Wee Kiat]] || 2003 || English || Singapore Philatelic Museum || 16 || covers stamps, currency and phone cards featuring ''Nepenthes''; single-page foreword and appendix not included in page count || |} ==Notes== {{refbegin}} :a.{{Note_label|A|a|none}}Year 2552 in the [[Thai solar calendar]]. {{refend}} ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==External links== * [http://www.sarracenia.com/faq/faq6010a.html Ivo's Book List] at The Carnivorous Plant FAQ ([http://ivo.koudela.sweb.cz/books.txt updated list]) {{Nepenthes monographs}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Nepenthes literature, List of}} [[Category:Nepenthes literature| *]] [[Category:Literature lists|Nepenthes literature]]

revision.comment: Blue series publication numbers 8 & 9 reversed to correct order.
revision.text:
{{unsourced|date=March 2009}} The '''''Puddle Lane'' children's books''' were published by [[Ladybird Books]] during the second half of the 1980s. The stories were based on a TV program of the same name (see [[Puddle Lane]]). [[Sheila K McCullagh]], who wrote the stories for the TV program, also wrote the books.
Five sets of books were produced, the first set being the easiest to read (Reading Programme Stage 1). Books of each set featured a distinct cover colour. All books are in hardcover format, 7 inches tall and 4.75 inches wide (standard Ladybird format). Here's a list of all 54 books in the series:
==Stage 1 (blue covers)== # Tim Catchamouse (31 Oct 1985) # Tessa and the Magician (31 Oct 1985) # The Magic Box (31 Oct 1985) # Mrs Pitter-Patter And The Magician (31 Oct 1985) # The Vanishing Monster (31 Oct 1985) # The Wideawake Mice (31 Oct 1985) # The Flying Saucer (31 Oct 1985) # Two Green Ears (30 Jan 1986) # The Tale Of A Tail (31 Oct 1985) # The Griffle And Mr Gotobed (30 Jan 1986) # Look out! It's magic! (30 Jan 1986) # Tim Turns Green (30 Jan 1986) # Tom Cat And The Wideawake Mice (30 Jan 1986) # Jeremy Mouse And Mr Puffle (30 Jan 1986) # Toby Spelldragon And The Magician (30 Jan 1986) # How Miranda Flew Down Puddle Lane (29 Jan 1987) # The Wideawake Mice Find A New Home (29 Jan 1987) # The Monster Loses His Beard (29 Jan 1987) # A Present for Aunt Matilda (29 Jan 1987) # Jeremy's Ride (29 Jan 1987) # Poor Peter Tall (29 Jan 1987)
==Stage 2 (green covers)== # When The Magic Stopped (31 Oct 1985) # Tessa in Puddle Lane (31 Oct 1985) # The Little Monster (31 Oct 1985) # The Dragon's Egg (31 Oct 1985) # The Gruffle (30 Jan 1986) # The Tidy Bird (30 Jan 1986) # Never Trust Dragons (30 Jan 1986) # The Wideawake Mice Go To Market (30 Jan 1986) # Danger! Dragon! (29 Jan 1987) # Magic Balloons (29 Jan 1987) # The Griffle And The Thief (29 Jan 1987) # Mr Grimble Grumbles (29 Jan 1987) # Adventure in the Wood (28 Jan 1988) # Mr Puffle and the Gruffle (28 Jan 1988) # Danger in the Magician's Garden (28 Jan 1988) # The Fox And The Magician (28 Jan 1988)
==Stage 3 (orange covers)== # Old Mr Gotobed (31 Oct 1985) # Hickory Mouse (31 Oct 1985) # The Gruffle In Puddle Lane (30 Jan 1986) # The Magician's Party (30 Jan 1986) # The Magic Penny (30 Jan 1986) # Three Wishes And One More (29 Jan 1987) # Peter Puffle's Mouse (28 Jan 1988) # The Magic Dust (28 Jan 1988) # The Rescue of Father & Mother Mouse (28 Jan 1988) # Magic at Midnight (28 Jan 1988)
==Stage 4 (purple covers)== # When The Clock Struck Thirteen (31 Oct 1985) # The Sandalwood Girl (31 Oct 1985) # On The Way To The Blue Mountains (30 Jan 1986) # The Fire in the grass (30 Jan 1986) # The Silver River (30 Jan 1986)
==Stage 5 (red covers)== # The Magician's Raindrops (1 May 1987) # A Dragon In The Mountains (29 Jan 1987)
==Special Books== # Christmas in Puddle Lane (1 Oct 1987)<sup>1</sup> # The Big Puddle Lane Storybook (28 Jan 1988)<sup>1</sup>
<sup>1</sup>Additionally, two standalone books were produced: ''Christmas in Puddle Lane'' and ''The Big Puddle Lane Story Book'', both written by Sheila McCullagh. They contained several new stories and some songs.
[[Category:Lists of books|Puddle Lane]]

page.title: List of fictional literature featuring opera

revision.comment: Fixed table cell placement on previous edit
revision.text:
{{refimprove|date=May 2014}} This is a list of literary fiction which feature [[opera]] in the plot. "Features" excludes fleeting mentions: for a literary work to be on this list opera must be a significant part of the plot, or, alternatively, provide significant context and backdrop. {| class="wikitable" |- ! scope="col" style="width:15%;"| Author ! scope="col" style="width:25%;"| Title ! scope="col" style="width:25%;"|Bibliographic information ! scope="col" style="width:35%;"|Remarks |- |[[Martha Albrand]]|| ''Final Encore'' ||New York: St. Martin's Press, 1978 {{ISBN|0312289413}} ||Alternative title: ''Intermission'' |- |[[Kingsley Amis]] || ''[[The Alteration]]'' ||London: Cape, 1976 {{ISBN|9780224013055}} ||Inspired by Amis's hearing of the [[castrato]] [[Alessandro Moreschi]]; the lead character is a choir boy who undergoes castration |- |Oskar Paul Wilhelm Anwand || ''Die Primadonna Friedrichs des Grossen'' || Berlin: R. Bong, 1930 ||Fictionalized account of the love affair between [[Gertrud Elisabeth Mara]] and [[Frederick the Great]] |- |[[Honoré de Balzac]] || ''Gambara'' ||New York: New York Review Books, 2001 {{ISBN|9780940322745}}||features an opera by its eponymous composer on the life of [[Muhammad|Mahomet]], as well as a disquisition on [[Giacomo Meyerbeer|Meyerbeer]]'s opera ''[[Robert le diable]]'' |- |Eva Fanny Bernhardine Turk Baudissin, Grafin von || ''[[Wilhelmine Schröder-Devrient]]: der Schicksalsweg einer großen Künstlerin'' ||Berlin: Drei Masken Verlag, 1937 || |- |[[Malcolm Bradbury]]||''Rates of Exchange'' ||London: Secker & Warburg, 1983 {{ISBN|9780436065057}} ||features the interminable Slakan national opera ''[[Vedontakal Vrop]]'', by Z. Leblat |- | Malcolm Bradbury ||''Why come to [[Slaka (fiction)|Slaka]]?'' ||London: Secker & Warburg, 1986 {{ISBN|9780436065064}} ||again features the interminable Slakan national opera ''Vedontakal Vrop'' |- |{{ill|Friedrich Bruckbräu|de}} || ''Mittheilungen aus den geheimen Memoiren einer deutschen Sängerin''; later issued as ''Aus den Memoiren einer Sängerin''
